titleStmt.title: Microstructure and mechanical properties of Re x NbMoTaW highentropy alloys prepared by arc melting using metal powders

analytic.title: Microstructure and mechanical properties of Re x NbMoTaW highentropy alloys prepared by arc melting using metal powders

biblStruct.note: Received 16 December 2019 Received in revised form 8 February 2020 Accepted 10 February 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High-entropy alloys Segregation Grain refinement Mechanical properties

div.p: A series of refractory Re x NbMoTaW high entropy alloys were developed with the addition of Re into the NbMoTaW alloy. The Re x NbMoTaW alloys are composed of body-centered cubic (BCC) matrix phase and particle phase and could maintain the phase structure up to their melting points. All the alloys possess precipitations due to the higher surface energy in powders raw material than rods. The proper addition of Re could improve both the strength and ductility of the alloys, and Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy exhibits the best mechanical properties. As the Re addition increases from 0 to 0.5, the yield strength of the alloys is improved from 1058 MPa to 1147 MPa, while the room-temperature ductility increases from 2.6% to 7.0%.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: High entropy alloys (HEAs) were firstly launched by Yeh et al. in 2004, and the main principle is to maximize the configurational entropy by increasing the number of principal components [1,2]. Due to their high mixing entropy, these alloys tend to form singlephase structures with high symmetry, such as FCC (face-centered cubic), BCC (body-centered cubic), and HCP (hexagonal closepacked) [3,4]. The high mixing entropy is also anticipated to enhance the stabilization of solid solution phases and impede dislocation motion, thereby improving the mechanical properties. Consequently, HEAs have been demonstrated to exhibit a variety of exceptional properties such as high hardness, outstanding wear resistance, good structural stability, high-temperature strength, etc. [5,6].

Since metallic alloys for high-temperature load-bearing structures and thermal protection systems remain in high demand for aerospace applications, HEAs composed of high melting point elements, such as HfNbTaZr [7], CrMoNbTa [8], CrNbVZr [9] or NbMoTaW [10e12] element groupings, have been explored. In these HEAs, NbMoTaW and VNbMoTaW produced by vacuum arcmelting exhibit excellent yield strength of 506 MPa and 735 MPa at 1200 C, respectively [12]. However, the alloys showed limited room temperature ductility with the plastic strain of about 2.0% and 1.5%, respectively, which might be a limitation for further industrial applications.

It is well known that alloying has long been used to achieve better properties than individual metals. Alloying typically involves the addition of relatively small amounts of secondary elements to a primary element, which as obstacles to dislocation motion and resulting in increased strength or hardness [13]. For example, Han et al. have successfully synthesized TiNbMoTaW and TiVNbMoTaW refractory HEAs with better room-temperature ductility by adding Ti element [14]. The addition of ductile Ti with a large atomic size improves the strength and fracture strain of HEAs but reduces the overall melting temperature of HEAs due to the low melting temperature of Ti. Dong et al. [15] improved the mechanical properties of AlCoCrFeNi alloy by adding 0.2 at% V. The compressive strength and plastic strain were increased from 2865 MPa to 3298 MPa and 22.7%e26.8%, respectively.

Element Re has a small atomic size and a high melting temperature. The addition of Re can raise the strength and improve the ductility of W by reducing the Peierls stress due to the changes in 1= 2111 screw dislocation from a symmetric to an asymmetric core and reduction ductile-brittle transition temperature of W [16,17]. Gornostyrev et al. [18] also reported that the Re element has a ductilization effect, which can increase the strength and plasticity of W and Mo alloys with BCC structure. In addition, powders have large specific surface areas, which can promote solubility and element activity. The particle configuration is easy to flow and mix, and can be accurately weighed and controlled. Therefore, we have designed and prepared novel Re x NbMoTaW alloys by arc melting using powder raw materials. The influence of Re addition on the microstructure and mechanical properties of these alloys is investigated and discussed in this study.

div.head: Experimental procedures
div.p: Raw materials Re, Mo, Ta, Nb, and W were in the form of metallic powder with purities of all above 99.95% and an average diameter of 40 mm. Metallic powders were mixed in corresponding ratio.

Re x NbMoTaW alloys (x Â¼ 0, 0.5 and 1 in molar ratio, denoted as Re0, Re0.5 and Re1, respectively) were prepared by vacuum arc melting the mixture of the corresponding elements. The powders were well mixed by manual grinding, compressed under the pressure. Arc melting of the alloys was on a water-cooled copper plate conducted under a protective argon atmosphere. To achieve a homogeneous distribution of elements, the arc-melted pellets were flipped and remelted five times. All the alloy ingots were about 8 mm in thickness and about 20 mm in diameter.

The phase purity of the arc-melted alloys was determined by Xray Diffraction with Cu-Ka radiation (Rigaku Ultima III, Japan). The diffraction pattern was recorded from a 2q (diffraction angle) range from 20 to 140 with a step size of 0.02 at a rate of 4 min Ã1 . Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, FEI the Quanta 250 FEG, US) was used to analyze the microstructure after alloys etched by the mixture of hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid and distilled water (V HF : V HNO3 : V H2O Â¼ 1: 1: 2). The average grain size was statistically analyzed using quantitative metallography by the software of Image-Pro Plus 6.0 based on more than 200 grains and 500 particles, respectively, from the BSED-SEM images of the sintered samples. Electron probe microanalyzer (EPMA, JOEL JXA-8230) was used to analyze the element distribution and chemical compositions. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to analyze the microstructure at 200 kV. The thin foil samples were cut from the cross-section of alloys, mechanically polished, and then ion-beam thinned down.

The Vickers hardness was measured on polished cross-section surfaces under a 1 kg load applied for 15 s. Each specimen was tested at room temperature and reported as the averages of five measurement results. The room-temperature compressive properties were conducted on an Instron 5966 testing machine at a constant loading speed of 0.5 mm/min. The specimens for compression tests were in the shape of cylinder with F 2 mm Ã 4 mm. At least five samples were tested for each composition on the same testing condition.

div.head: Phase prediction
div.p: In this work, FactSage 6.4 software (GTT-Technologies, Germany) [19] has been used to construct the phase diagram of the Re x NbMoTaW refractory alloys shown in Fig. 1a. A single BCC phase is predicted to form below the melting point of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys and remains stable at a broad temperature range. However, an HCP (hexagonal close-packed) phase is expected to occur as the temperature decreases to about 1000 C. As the alloys were melted with quick cooling rate, the non-equilibrium solidification is simulated. The non-equilibrium mole fraction versus temperature for the Re 1.0 NbMoTaW alloy is shown in Fig. 1b. The BCC phase is found to form without phase transformation.

Several physical parameters have also been proposed to predict the phase formation and structural stability in HEAs [20e25]. From a thermodynamic point of view, and in particular, derived from Hume-Rothery rules, Guo et al. [20] suggested a criterion for achieving solid-solution phases in HEAs using three parameters, DH mix (enthalpy of mixing), d (atomic radius difference), and DS mix (entropy of mixing). Using available data from various HEAs systems, the criteria for forming solid solutions in HEAs were determined to be: 0 d 8.5, Ã22 DH mix 7 kJ/mol, and 11 DS mix 19.5 J/(K$mol). An additional parameter U was also proposed [21], which supposed that the effect of entropy of mixing must overshadow the enthalpy of mixing in order to favor the formation of high-entropy phases. From the available literature, it was concluded that the criteria for forming solid solution are U ! 1:1 and d 6:6% [21]. The other parameter g (the ratio between the solid angles of the smallest and largest atoms) was introduced by Wang et al. [22]. It is an indicator to reveal the atomic packing misfitting and topological instability. The application of g in phase selection in HEAs and superalloys indicates that it is more efficient at distinguishing solid solutions from intermetallics than the previous polydispersity parameter of atomic size difference d. And g < 1:175is one of the necessary conditions for determining the solubility of multicomponent alloys. In order to form single-phase solid solution (SPSS), parameter L (L Â¼ DS mix =d 2 ) has been prescribed by Singh et al. and the criteria is L > 0.96 [23]. A new model using high-throughput computation of the formation enthalpies DH f of possible binary compounds has also been developed to predict the specific combinations of elements that are most likely to form SPSS [25]. It shows that single solid solution would be formed under the condition of -T ann DS mix < DÐ f < 37 meV/mol, where the annealing temperature is T ann ~0.6T m , T m is melting temperature.

Table 1 shows the calculated values of parameters d, DH mix , DS mix , U, g, L, and DH f of Re x NbMoTaW according to different proposed prediction models. All the parameters except DH f are in the range of forming a solid solution for Re x NbMoTaW alloys. Meanwhile, the alloys tend to form single-phase solid solutions according to the SPSS forming rule. For the formation enthalpy DH f , -T ann DS mix for Re0, Re0.5 and Re1 are calculated to be Ã193 meV/ mol, Ã222 meV/mol and Ã228 meV/mol, respectively. Thus, the DH f of ReTa and MoTa compounds are at the minimum boundaries.

Meanwhile, no MoTa and ReTa compounds are formed according to the MoeTa and ReeTa binary alloy phase diagrams [26]. Therefore, combining the calculation of phase diagram and physical parameters prediction, it is expected to single phase Re x NbMoTaW alloys. With all the peaks indexed, all the as-casted alloys are identified to be a single solid solution with the BCC crystal structure. Fig. 2 (b) shows the enlarged scans for the (110) peak of Re x NbMoTaW alloys. With increasing Re addition, the peaks of the alloys shift to higher 2q, indicating that the lattice constants decrease with increasing Re addition. The diffraction peaks were used to calculate the lattice constants of the alloys with high accuracy and the lattice constants are determined to be a 1 Â¼ 3.212 Ã for Re0, a 2 ï¼3.202 Ã for Re0.5 and a 3 Â¼ 3.193 Ã for Re1. The decreasing of lattice constants with Re addition is mainly due to the small atomic radius of Re, which is smaller compared with other elements in the Re x NbMoTaW alloys.

div.head: Microstructural analysis
div.p: The theoretical lattice constants (a mix ) of alloys can be calculated using the rule of mixtures approach:
div.formula: a mix Â¼ X c i a i
div.p: where c i and a i are the atomic percent and lattice constant of element i, respectively. The lattice parameters of pure elements were taken from Ref. [27], and the calculated a mix for the studied alloys are given in Table 2. As comparison, the difference between the calculated and experimental lattice constants is less than 1%, revealing that the lattice constants follow well with the rule of mixtures within experimental errors, and the BCC phase is a fully disordered solid solution. Meanwhile, the calculated lattice parameters are smaller than the experimental one, indicating that some ordering solution may be formed [28]. SEM images of the as-cast Re x NbMoTaW alloys after etching are shown in Fig. 3. All the Re x NbMoTaW alloys are composed of BCC matrix phase and particle precipitation phase. Fig. 3 (d) shows the average grain size of the matrix phase. With the increasing of Re addition the grain size of the BCC matrix decreases and then increases. Re0.5 has the smallest grain size. From the EDS analysis of Re x NbMoTaW alloys (shown in Table 3) and EPMA analysis of the Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy (shown in Fig. 4), the overall measured element compositions are similar to the designed ones. The element segregation characteristics can be visualized: Ta is uniformly distributed, more W and Mo solidify in the matrix, and more Nb precipitated in the particle phase. Thus, the particle phase is enriched with Nb and Ta. A representative bright-field TEM image of the Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy is presented in Fig. 5, which indicates the two phases presenting in the alloy system. The selected diffraction patterns of the matrix (A) and particles (B) are indexed, revealing matrix (A) with a BCC crystal structure. The particle phase (B) has a tetragonal structure with the lattice parameters of a Â¼ 10.056 Ã , c Â¼ 5.438 Ã . The element distribution of phases obtained by TEM-EDS is presented in Fig. 6. The particle phase is enriched with Nb and Ta, which is in a good agreement with the result of EPMA.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: The Vickers hardness values of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys are listed in Table 4. As the Re addition increases from 0 to 1, the microhardness increases first and then decreases. The highest hardness of 567 Â± 9 HV is obtained for Re0.5. Meanwhile, the theoretical microhardness could be calculated according to the mixing rule: Hv mix Â¼ P c i Ã°HvÃ i , where (Hv) i is the Vickers harness of element i. The measured hardness of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys is higher than the theoretical ones, which is mainly due to solid solution strengthening caused by the severe lattice distortion of alloys.

The compressive engineering stress-strain curves of Re x NbMo-TaW alloys at room temperature are presented in Fig. 7, based on which the original mechanical parameters of the alloys listed in Table 5. As the Re addition increases from 0 to 1, the yield strength, compressive strength, and fracture strain of Re x NbMoTaW alloys exhibit similar trend as the microhardness increasing firstly and then decreasing. Re0.5 alloy reached the highest mechanical properties, with the yield strength, maximum strength, and fracture strain of 1147 Â± 10 MPa, 1465 Â± 18 MPa, and 7.01 Â± 0.30%, respectively.

To consider the possible mechanisms that might result in the variations in the tested alloys, it is instructive to examine the fracture morphology. Fig. 8 shows the fracture morphologies of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys, which match well with observed mechanical properties of the alloys. The Re1 alloy shows a typical cleavage fracture. The fracture is straight and smooth, showing long river patterns. The Re0 and Re0.5 alloys exhibit quasi cleavage fracture, in which the river patterns are short and curved, and torn edges are formed. Compared with Re0, the Re0.5 alloy has more tearing edges, indicating better ductility. In addition, from the enlarged image of the Re0.5 alloy shown in Fig. 8(b'), the crack ends or changes direction around the precipitated phase, indicating that the precipitated phase can effectively improve the mechanical properties of the alloys.

div.head: Phase formation
div.p: Through the theoretical prediction, single BCC solid solution would be expected to form in the Re x NbMoTaW alloys. However, BCC solid solution and (Nb, Ta)-rich phase are formed in the obtained microstructure, which is inconsistent with the predicted one. Previously, Senkov et al. [12] reported the NbMoTaW alloy with a single BCC phase produced using arc melting of chips. The NbMoTaW HEA (donated as A1) in this study was fabricated using raw materials in powder configurations, which probably results in the formation of (Nb, Ta)-rich precipitations.

In order to explain the occurrence of (Nb, Ta)-rich particles, we fabricated another sets of NbMoTaW alloys, for which the re-melted time was increased from 5 times to 10 times. The SEM images of NbMoTaW alloys melted for different times are shown in Fig. 9. As increasing the re-melted times, the NbMoTaW alloy changes to be a single BCC phase. Therefore, the precipitation of the (Nb, Ta)-rich particles is mainly due to the raw materials of powders. It is widely known that powders have more surface energy than rods [29,30]. When changing the raw materials from rods to powders, the total energy of alloys increases under the condition of the same melting technological parameters. Thus, it is easier for alloys prepared by powders to form a metastable phase during solidification [31,32]. Meanwhile, as Nb and Ta have a bigger radius than other elements [32,33], a large solution of Nb and Ta will increase the lattice distortion of HEA. Therefore, the particle phase enriched with Nb and Ta precipitates.

div.head: Strengthening mechanisms
div.p: In the Re x NbMoTaW alloys, the Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy with the smallest grain size exhibits the highest microhardness and strength. It is well known that the relationship between the strength s and average grain size d can be described by the classic Hall-Petch equation:
div.formula: s Â¼ s 0 Ã¾ k,d Ã1=2
div.p: where s 0 is the lattice friction, and k is the strengthening coefficient. The strength of the alloy is inversely proportional to the square root of the grain size. The mechanical properties of the alloys can be improved by refining the grain size. The key of finegrain strengthening lies in the effect of grain boundary on dislocation slip, which acts as pinning points impeding further dislocation propagation The impeding in dislocation movement hinders the onset of plasticity and hence leads to the improvement of the alloy strength. For the Re x NbMoTaW alloys, the smaller the grain size is, the more the grain boundary areas are, and the higher the strength is. Therefore, the Re 0.5 NbMoTaW HEA has high strength and hardness. Fine-grain strengthening is found to be an important strengthening mechanism in Re x NbMoTaW alloys. As Senkov et al. reported [12], NbMoTaW alloy with single BCC solid solution has microhardness, yield strength, and compressive strength of 445.5 Hv, 1058 MPa and 1211 MPa, respectively. However, the Re0 alloy with BCC and (Nb, Ta)-rich phases in this study has higher hardness and strength, indicating that the second phase strengthens the Re0 alloy. Meanwhile, from Fig. 8(b'), the crack ends or changes direction around the precipitated phase, which leads to dispersion enhancement. Thus, the strengthening mechanism of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys is the combination of fine-grain strengthening and second phase strengthening.

Grain refinement can improve not only the strength of alloys but also the ductility of alloys at the same time. The Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy with smaller grain size has better ductility, which is mainly due to the grain refinement of the BCC matrix phase. During the plastic deformation, the deformation of the fine-grain alloy is dispersed in more grains, so the deformation is more uniform, the alloy can bear more deformation before fracture.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, novel refractory Re x NbMoTaW alloys were designed and synthesized by arc melting the mixture of pure metallic powders. From the theoretical prediction, single BCC solid solution would be formed in the Re x NbMoTaW alloys. The Re x NbMoTaW alloys are actually composed of BCC solid solution and (Nb, Ta)-rich particle phase with tetragonal structure. With increasing Re addition, the grain size of BCC matrix decreases and then increases and Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy has the smallest one. The difference between the calculated and experimental results might be due to the usage of powder raw materials, which has high surface energy. The hardness, strength, and ductility of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys increase firstly and then decreases. The Re 0.5 NbMoTaW alloy reaches the maximum hardness, yield strength, compressive strength and fracture strain of 567 Â± 9 HV, 1147 Â± 10 MPa, 1465 Â± 18 MPa, and 7.01 Â± 0.30%, respectively. The strength enhancement of the Re x NbMoTaW alloys can be interpreted by the second phase strengthening and fine grain strengthening effect. The improved ductility can be understood by the fine grain strengthening mechanism. The excellent mechanical performance and high thermal stability of these HEAs make them hold potentials for applications as structural materials.
